{{also|mogen}} ==German== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|de|goh|mugan}}, from {{inh|de|gem-pro|*maganą}}, from {{der|de|ine-pro|*megʰ-}}. Compare {{cog|nl|mogen}}, {{cog|en|may}}, {{cog|is|mega}}, {{cog|got|𐌼𐌰𐌲𐌰𐌽}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|de|/ˈmøːɡən/|[ˈmøːɡən]|[ˈmøːɡŋ̩]}} * {{audio|de|De-mögen.ogg}} * {{a|Austria}} {{audio|de|De-at-mögen.ogg}} ===Verb=== {{de-verb-irregular|mag|mochte|gemocht|past subjunctive=[[möchte]]}} # {{lb|de|transitive}} to [[like]] (something or someone) #: {{ux|de|Ich '''mag''' keinen Käse.|I don't '''like''' cheese.|inline=1}} # {{lb|de|intransitive}} to [[want]] to [[go]] # {{lb|de|auxiliary|with infinitive}} [[may]] {{qualifier|expresses a possibility, never a permission}} #: {{ux|de|Das '''mag''' ja alles stimmen.|That '''may''' all be true.|inline=1}} # {{lb|de|auxiliary|in negation|with infinitive}} to be [[hesitant]] to (do something) #: {{ux|de|Ich '''mag''' sie '''nicht''' fragen.|I '''am hesitant''' to ask her.|inline=1}} # {{lb|de|auxiliary|in the present subjunctive|with infinitive}} [[may]] {{qualifier|paraphrases the [[optative]]}}. #: {{ux|de|'''Möge''' die Macht mit dir sein.|'''May''' the Force be with you.|inline=1}} # {{lb|de|transitive|in the past subjunctive}} to [[want]]; would like (to have or to do something) #: {{ux|de|Ich '''möchte''' Käse.|I '''would like''' cheese.|inline=1}} #: {{ux|de|Ich '''möchte''' keinen Käse.|I don't '''want''' cheese.|inline=1}} # {{lb|de|auxiliary|in the past subjunctive|with infinitive|}} to [[want]] to; [[would like]] to; to [[wish]] to (do something) #: {{ux|de|Ich '''möchte''' sie nicht fragen.|I don't '''want''' to ask her.|inline=1}} ====Usage notes==== * As with all modal verbs, the past participle ''gemocht'' is used in the perfect tenses only when the verb is not followed by another infinitive: ''Käse habe ich noch nie '''gemocht'''.'' – “I've never '''liked''' cheese.” When an infinitive follows, ''mögen'' itself also stands in the infinitive (double infinitive construction): ''Ich habe sie nicht fragen '''mögen'''.'' – “I was hesitant to ask her.” * ''Möchte'' and its forms are grammatically the past subjunctive of ''mögen'', but are never used as such in contemporary German. The conditional of ''mögen'' needs to be paraphrased with {{m|de|würde}}: ''Wenn ich Käse '''mögen würde''', könnte ich viel mehr Gerichte essen.'' – “If I '''liked''' cheese, I could eat many more dishes.” * ''Möchte'' is in fact used as a somewhat more polite synonym of {{m|de|wollen||to want}} in the present indicative: ''Wenn ich Käse '''möchte''', sage ich dir bescheid.'' – “If I '''want''' cheese, I'll let you know.” (synonymous with: ''Wenn ich Käse '''will''',''...). In colloquial German, the split between ''mögen'' and ''möchte'' is so clear-cut that the latter may be interpreted as an independent verb and hence used in the infinitive: ''Du hast hier gar nix zu '''möchten'''!'' – “You're not in the position to express wishes!” This is, however, nonstandard. * In dated or regional speech, the present indicative of ''mögen'' may be used interchangeably with ''möchte'', particularly in questions: '''''Magst''' du was trinken?'' – “'''Would''' you '''like''' something to drink?” This is normal in Austro-Bavarian areas. In most other regions it is less common and likely to sound affected. ====Conjugation==== {{de-conj-pp|mög|mag|moch|möch|gemocht|h}} ====Related terms==== * {{l|de|möglich}} * {{l|de|vermögen}} ====Descendants==== * {{desc|bor=1|gmw-cfr|müjje}} ===Further reading=== * {{R:Duden}} [[Category:German modal verbs]] ---- ==Low German== ===Alternative forms=== * {{alter|nds|mägen}} * {{l|nds|mügen}} {{q|Paderbornisch}} ===Etymology=== From {{inh|nds|gml|mȫgen}}, from {{inh|nds|osx|mugan}}, from {{inh|nds|gem-pro|*maganą}}, from {{der|nds|ine-pro|*megʰ-}}. Compare {{cog|de|mögen}}, {{cog|nl|mogen}}, {{cog|en|may}}, {{cog|is|mega}}, {{cog|got|𐌼𐌰𐌲𐌰𐌽}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|nds|/ˈmœːɣən/|/ˈmœː.ŋ/}} {{a|Mecklenburg, Pomerania, Brandenburg, conservative dialects in northern Lower Saxony}} * {{IPA|nds|/ˈmøːɣən/|/ˈmøː.ŋ/}} {{a|Eastphalia, Lippe, less conservative dialects in northern Lower Saxony}} ===Verb=== {{head|nds|verb|third-person singular simple present|mag|past tense|much|past participle|mucht|auxiliary verb|hebben}} # {{lb|nds|auxiliary}} [[may]], [[can]], [[be]] [[allowed]] to. #: ''He '''mag''' düt Johr nich in de Ferien föhren.'' #:: He '''isn't allowed to''' drive during the vacation this year. # {{lb|nds|auxiliary}} used to express [[presumption]], often used as the English ''[[should]]'' #: ''Dat '''mag''' al Klock söven wesen!'' #:: It '''should''' already be 7 o'clock! # {{lb|nds|auxiliary}} to [[wish]] [[to]], to [[would]] [[like]] [[to]] #: ''He '''mag''' geern fröh opwaken'' #:: He '''has the intention to''' wake up early # {{lb|nds|auxiliary}} often used with [[glöven]] or [[seggen]], emphasizes their meaning #: ''Dat '''magst''' du woll seggen!'' #:: It '''is''' well said! # {{lb|nds|transitive}} to be allowed to [[have]]/[[take]], to [[may]] [[have]] {{gloss|used as a polite way to request something}} #: '''''Möögt''' wi en Glas Melk?'' #:: '''May''' we '''have''' a glass of milk? # {{lb|nds|transitive}} To [[like]]. #: ''Ik '''mag''' em nich so geern.'' #:: I don't '''like''' him that much. ====Conjugation==== {{nds-conj-table|head=''mögen'' (preterite-present verb)|mag|magst|mag|möögt|much|muchst|much|muchen|—|—|mögen|mucht}} ===Usage notes=== The old subjunctive II form ''müch'' is used to express a wish. It can also be used along with an infinitive with the meaning "to want, would like, wish". ====Synonyms==== * {{sense|may}} {{l|nds|könen}}, {{l|nds|künnen}} * {{sense|want}} {{l|nds|wüllen}}, {{l|nds|wünschen}} * {{sense|like}} {{l|nds|leefhebben}}
